entry.title: Let‚Äôs Talk About Clean Core
entry.content:
What is Clean Core?

In simple terms: Clean Core is the practice of keeping the core of SAP S/4HANA as ‚Äúclean‚Äù and standardized as possible.

This means avoiding heavy customizations directly in the system core and, instead, using extensions, APIs, and official tools provided by SAP. By doing so, your company can:

  • Upgrade the system with less effort.

  • Reduce maintenance costs.

  • Adopt innovations much faster.

üëâ More details here: SAP Clean Core Methodology

Why is this important?

In SAP ECC, it was common for companies to change the central code to meet specific needs. The result? A heavy, rigid system ‚Äî expensive to upgrade and always slowing down the move to the cloud.

Clean Core was born to break this cycle. It allows your company to take advantage of SAP‚Äôs continuous updates without the ‚Äúheadaches,‚Äù while staying agile enough to innovate.

A Simple Analogy: Tidying Up the House

Think about it like this:

  • If you organize your house the way Marie Kondo suggests ‚Äî everything in its place ‚Äî it‚Äôs much easier to keep order every day.

  • But if you only tidy up when guests arrive, you‚Äôll spend way more time and energy, and probably still leave things out of place.

Clean Core works the same way: you keep the system organized from the start, instead of ‚Äúfixing things‚Äù only when a new upgrade or version migration arrives.

So, Where Should You Customize?

Here‚Äôs the strategic insight: not everything needs customization.

Accounting reports, tax invoices, legal requirements‚Ä¶ these are standardized and can follow SAP‚Äôs market-ready models, especially in the Cloud Public Edition.

That frees up time and budget for what really matters: the processes that differentiate your business and make customers choose you.

And it‚Äôs there ‚Äî in these unique areas ‚Äî that you should apply business intelligence and customizations, using the right S/4HANA tools (such as in-app extensions or side-by-side developments on SAP BTP).

In Summary

Clean Core is more than a technical recommendation. It‚Äôs a system management philosophy:

  • Keep what is standard truly standard.

  • Customize only where your competitive advantage lies.

  • Always think about why your company exists and the value it delivers to customers.

That way, every update will be smooth, every innovation easier to adopt, and the company‚Äôs focus will remain on what creates real market impact.

entry.title: Dashboard and Business AI Insights for SAP License Simulation and Analysis
entry.content:
Introduction

SAP has introduced the SAM4U solution, an excellent tool to gather data from SAP backend systems for the consolidation and analysis of users, engines, and HANA EE license consumption.

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, available on SAP Store, provides extended analytics and simulation capabilities to view SAM4U data from new angles. It empowers customers moving to S/4HANA, S/4HANA Private Cloud, or already working under an SAP RISE contract to run different ‚Äúwhat if‚Äù scenarios based on data extracted from their SAP system, helping them find the best approach to optimize SAP license consumption.

What Was Missing?

While SAM4U provides valuable transparency, customers often asked:

  • How do I see the potential savings?

  • How do I define a strategy for optimization?

  • Where exactly should I focus my cleanup efforts?

License optimization typically falls into three categories:

  • Fast optimization: achieved quickly with user data cleanup in SAP backend

  • Obtainable optimization: achievable in reasonable time with cleanup and role/profile tuning

  • Maximal optimization: the long-term goal, achieved when roles and authorizations are precisely aligned with actual usage

What was missing was clarity and insights to navigate these paths effectively.

How it is solved

The new release of the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings two major updates:

  • Clarity through an extremely informative dashboard

  • Business AI insights powered by the Skybuffer AI platform, an SAP Business AI certified solution from SAP Store

The dashboard

This is the highlight. The dashboard presents clear KPIs on one page, helping to get insights into current estimated spending and estimated savings, following both fast and obtainable strategies.

 Pic. 1 The Dashboard

One of the central KPIs is License Optimization Potential, which shows the estimated current contract costs compared to optimized contract costs. The KPI highlights savings that can be achieved either through the fast users cleanup approach or the obtainable approach of cleaning up users and optimizing roles with the highest optimization potential.

 Pic. 2 License Optimization Potential

There are many other useful insights. For example, it shows how many authorization objects are not used at all. This is a target for maximal optimization and one reason it is not so easily obtainable. The lower the number, the better the authorizations are aligned with active usage.

 Pic. 3 Excess Authorization

The evaluation of maximal optimization is also visualized by the FUE Gap KPI:

 Pic. 4 FUE Gap - Authorization vs Active Usage

There is also a very helpful hint about SAP_ALL and SAP_NEW profiles still in use in production:

 Pic. 5 Users with Sensitive Authorization Profiles

The total number of roles and profiles that can be optimized and the savings this brings are also clearly summarized:

 Pic. 6 Excess Roles

The insights

Business AI insights in the dashboard bring extra clarity and understanding. For example, they show the fast optimization saving potential and provide clear explanations and strategies on how to reach it:

Pic. 7 Business AI Insights

AI recommendations are also available for obtainable or maximal optimization:

 Pic. 8 Max and Obtainable Optimization

Effectively, this functions as a personal SAP License Analysis and Optimization consultant, virtualized and trained to understand the organization‚Äôs own data.

The AI Assistant is always there, and expanding its knowledge base is straightforward through the Skybuffer AI platform. For example, it can present the top 10 roles for optimization or provide additional information related to SAP licensing:

 Pic. 9 Top 10 Roles for Optimization

Of course, all the well-established simulation and analysis tools of the Accelerator remain available. With the new release, they work even better, helping to test and simulate the AI Assistant‚Äôs recommendations.

Conclusion

The Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption now provides one of the most powerful toolsets on the market to analyze and optimize SAP users and engines licenses independently. It helps avoid the significant costs of SAP license optimization consulting and delivers deep insights into user and engine data. This comes without the need for a complex SAM4U installation and without spending time and money on consulting services that quickly become outdated.

What to do next?

Running SAP under a RISE contract? Use the dashboard and Business AI insights at least once per month to avoid FUE consumption increases and surprises. Train your team with the solution and the organization will not face unpredictable growth of SAP license consumption. Leave consulting for the exceptional case when the company grows faster than its SAP role set. üòâ

entry.title: Using the SAP EarlyWatch Alert Status App
entry.content:
SAP Note 1257308 - FAQ: Using EarlyWatch Alert provides preliminary information about the Status App. The app tracks the status of the SAP EarlyWatch Alert (EWA) from the arrival of service data through all processing steps at SAP. This app is intended for administrators to troubleshoot the EWA process. This blog will provide a more detailed description of the Status App functionality.

EWA session data can be sent to SAP through various methods. The EWA session data can be sent directly to SAP through the HTTP destination SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL (via SAP-SUPPORT_PARCELBOX) from either an ABAP managed system or an SAP Solution Manager system. Additionally, any EWA session data for systems managed by the ECS team are sent via their SAP Focused Run systems on SAP side to be processed. The following Notes and KBAs are provided for more information on all three scenarios.

  • 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP
  • 1684537 - EarlyWatch Alert Not Sent to SAP: Troubleshooting Guide - SAP Solution Manager
  • 2930644 - SAP Focused Run: EarlyWatch Alert Troubleshooting Guide - Guided Answer

After sending EWA session data through one of the available methods it can be unclear whether the EWA data was successfully received by SAP or if there was any issue with the EWA session processing. The EWA Status App allows you to follow the status of your EWA report once it‚Äôs sent to SAP.

All EWA session data sent to SAP will be available for review in the EWA Status App, here you will find various details about the EWA sessions you have sent.

You can see the date the EWA session data session was sent, if they have been successfully received by SAP, as well as whether the EWA session could be processed successful or has been generated and posted in the EWA workspace.

Since the EWA session data packages sent to SAP are processed in randomly assigned batches for all customers it can take from a few hours to a few days for your EWA result to be available in various SAP applications like the EWA Workspace, Solution Finder, EWA Dashboard, or as a Word document available for download. Using the Status App allows you to track this process without opening a case.

The general fields available in the EWA Status App that are applicable for all system types are the following columns.

  • System
  • Product
  • Sending System Product
  • Data Received at SAP
  • Collected At

The ‚ÄúSystem‚Äù and ‚ÄúProduct‚Äù columns will list the long and short SID as well as the product version respectively of the EWA target system.

The ‚ÄúSending System Product‚Äù column, however, will display the product version of the system that transferred the session data to SAP. This is most often a Solution Manager or Focused Run system.  

Finally, the ‚ÄúData Received at SAP‚Äù and ‚ÄúCollected at‚Äù columns document the date and time the EWA session package was received by SAP as well as when it was collected on the managed system.

Data Transfer Status Details

In the EWA Status App the ‚ÄúData Transfer Status Details‚Äù column can have one of three status‚Äô. The status‚Äô are Rejected, Ignored, Success. As you would expect Success simply indicates the EWA session data was successfully transferred to SAP. The other two status‚Äô can be indicative of various errors. I will describe the most common in more detail below.

"Ignored (duplicate)"

This status indicates that the EWA is sent multiple times per week for the same system. You should check to see if the EWA is being sent from both Solution Manager and the managed system. The same checks should be performed for on prem FRUN systems. The EWA could also be sent multiple times per week from the same system. All will result in the same status.

"Ignored (not in allow list)"

This status can be caused by a few errors. However, the most common would be that either the license or maintenance certificate for the system is expired.

Recommendation:

Review the SLICENSE transaction in Solution Manager if used as well as the managed system to ensure both are up to date.

"Rejected (system time in future)"

The system runs with a system time deviating from official time. 

Recommendation:

The System Time can be synced manually by your system Admin. However, it is likely that this is a temporary change for testing purposes and it will sync automatically via Internet. If not working, your Admin can start this sync process at the OS Level.

 

"Rejected (no data)"

The service data that arrived at SAP is either not readable or empty or incomplete and thus important parts are completely missing.

Recommendation:

This would indicate that there are issues with EWA session data collection or service data quality. We recommend reviewing the resolution steps in the KBA 1824881 - Summary of Grey Rated EWA Reports - SAP Solution Manager.

"Rejected (non-productive)"

Only for productive and test systems the EWA is processed at SAP. Based on the system role the service data can be rejected. This is true for managed systems before ST-PI 740 SP23 (ST-PI 2008_1_7xx SP33) more information on the adjusted criteria can be found in SAP Note 207223 - SAP EarlyWatch Alert Processed at SAP.

"Rejected (not authorized)"

The technical communication user used for upload is not authorized to upload for this system.

Or

The technical communication user used for upload is not valid anymore.

Or

The user used for upload is not a technical communication user.

Recommendation:

You will need to ensure the S user assigned to both the SAP-SUPPORT_PORTAL and SAP-SUPPORT_PACELBOX HTTP destinations is a valid technical user. The following KBA outlines the requirements for the assigned user.

2174416 - Creation and activation of Technical Communication Users - SAP for Me

"Rejected (other reason)"

Create a case with component SV-SCS-EWA-GEN.

"Rejected (content size exceeds limit)"

The service data exceeds the size limit.

"Rejected (unknown system type)"

Supported technical system types are ABAP, HANA, JAVA and BOBJ. When extracting the leading system from the service data either no technical system type was determined, or the technical system type is not supported by EarlyWatch Alert.

Recommendation:

If using Solution Manager it is recommended that you review the system information maintained in LMDB. Ensure the technical system type is maintained and that it is a supported type.

In addition, in some scenarios is may be required to replace the SDCCN service definitions. The following KBA outlines the process and under which circumstances these steps should be performed.

SAP KBA 1765141 - When should the Service Definitions be completely replaced (Delete and Download) using the steps outlined in SAP Note 727998?

"Rejected (data too old)"

The service data that was sent to SAP was collected more than 112 days ago. Such old service data is not processed by SAP.

 

Details on Report Status, Dashboard Status, and Solution Finder Status

These three columns are relatively binary. The Status can either be ‚ÄúSuccess‚Äù or ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù / blank. In rare instances you can receive the status ‚ÄúError (Initialization Failed)‚Äù. In this instance a case should be opened in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

The Report Status will be successful when the EWA document has been successfully generated. Until this point this column will remain blank. As mentioned previously it can take from a few hours to several days for your EWA result to be available. If the EWA session data was successfully received by SAP there is no cause for concern if the EWA report is not immediately available.

The same is true of the columns ‚ÄúDashboard Status‚Äù and ‚ÄúSolution Finder Status‚Äù. When these applications are fully populated the EWA column status here in the Status App will change to Success. Prior to this the status will remain either blank or have the status ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù. Neither status is a cause for concern. If after several days the status of these columns remains unpopulated you should open a case in the SV-SMG-SER-EWA component area.

 

2 Billion Record Limit Status and Number Range Forecast Details

This column is system dependent. These checks are in reference to the maximum table size for HANA systems. The maximum table size cannot exceed 2 billion records for a HANA system without detrimental impact to the system.

However, the status ‚ÄúMissing‚Äù is most often applied to systems that do not have a HANA component. This information is not relevant to your system if you do not have a HANA Component and is not a cause for concern. You should review the EWA for the affected system to confirm that there is no associated HANA DB.

For HANA systems where this check was not successfully performed the status will instead be ‚ÄúNo Forecast‚Äù, ‚ÄúPartial Success‚Äù, or ‚ÄúUnconfident Forecast‚Äù.

These may be a cause for concern and your first steps should be to review the RTCCTOOL recommendations of both the managed system and Solution Manager. You are looking for any red warning objects related to HANA session data, ST-PI, or ST-A/PI.

More information about the exact limitations of HANA are documented in the KBA 2154870 - How-To: Understanding and defining SAP HANA Limitations.

Additionally, more information can be found in the HANA Sizing Blog.

entry.title: Workforce Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP¬¥s ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution. SAP S/4HANS Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem ‚Äì customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

Managing a skilled workforce efficiently is paramount for any growing organization. With the release 2508 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, businesses are empowered with robust HR connectivity options, which streamline workforce management activities. This article provides guidance on handling workforce data, work agreements, and user management using various technical integration options.

In traditional Identity Management (IDM) scenarios, HR systems usually take the lead in managing worker data and work agreements. Business user data might be managed directly in an IDM system or integrated via an HR system. The culmination of these processes sees the provisioning of worker data, work agreements, and business user data into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant through effective HR and IDM integration. Successful workforce management in this landscape hinges on strategic decisions about data creation through HR or IDM integration, based on which system leads.

 

Results: Realizing Workforce Management Scenarios


Imagine a scenario where SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is integrated with both the SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (using SAP Master Data Integration for HR) and an external IDM system via SOAP-based integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services. Here, aligning IDM integration as the leading choice brings forth several advantages.

 

Define Workforce Management System and Choose an Integration Option

  • IDM Integration Leads: Creating business user and worker data first allows users to access the system and perform tasks without needing pre-established work agreements.
  • HR Integration Leads: Worker data and work agreements are provisioned first, followed by business user creation, ensuring structured data flow.

To configure your scenario, access SAP Central Business Configuration for your specific tenant, locate the Define Workforce Management Scenario (106757) activity, and select your desired option: HR integration (default) or IDM integration. Currently, the default is ‚ÄúManage worker data using HR integration.‚Äù In this scenario, workforce data and work assignments must already exist in SAP S/4HANA Cloud through HR integration before business users can be created and assigned via IDM integration. The alternative ‚ÄúManage worker data using IDM integration‚Äù scenario allows the creation of workforce persons directly with the provisioning of user accounts through IDM integration, so business users can log in and perform tasks even before a work assignment is provided. The work assignment can then be provisioned later via the HR channel if required.

Please note: At this stage, the IDM-driven scenario is only available to customers participating in the Early Adopter Care (EAC) Program. If you are interested, alignment with the EAC Program Leads is required.

 

Flexible Data Management

With the integration setup, you can create worker and business user data within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition through the integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services or manually via the Manage Workforce or Maintain Business Users apps. However, once data is created through integration, it cannot be modified directly in these apps. The Entry Source field denotes where data can be edited and its origin. Refer to the Entry Source documentation for further information. If establishing a work agreement through HR integration precedes the creation of a worker record, an error will occur.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers businesses with flexible HR connectivity options for workforce management. By carefully selecting and implementing integration strategies, organizations can achieve efficient operations and seamless data management, essential for navigating the complex terrain of modern business environments. Choose the path that aligns best with your operational needs, ensuring a smooth and effective workforce management experience.

entry.title: Simulation for SAM4U Solution: Flexibility with the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption
entry.content:
When adopting SAP SAM4U, one of the biggest challenges customers face is handling role, profile, and authorization changes without disrupting production. This is where the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption brings real value, thanks to its simulation capabilities.

What Customers Expect from Authorization Simulation

With the simulation, customers get the ability to:

  • Log changes at the role or profile level on the system dataset.
  • Track and review roles and profiles that have been modified.
  • Revert changes at the role or profile level, either all at once or individually.
  • Modify user-to-role or user-to-profile assignments.
  • Perform mass unassignments of roles and profiles (e.g., removing SAP_ALL or SAP_NEW).
  • Identify and review changes made to users.
  • Revert user assignments back to their original state when needed.

 Pic. 01 Roles and Profiles Changes Tracking

 Pic. 02 Roles and Profiles Mass Unassignment

 Pic. 03 Changes to the Role Detailed Review

But that‚Äôs not all! The real power lies in managing simulation snapshots.

 Pic. 04 Snapshots of Simulations on the System‚Äôs Dataset Level

Why Simulation Snapshots Matter

Simulation snapshots are created at the system dataset level, allowing you to:

  • Save changes without applying them directly in production.
  • Create new consolidations from modified datasets.
  • Avoid repetitive, time-consuming rework when changes cannot be applied immediately.

Example: Working with Two Systems in Consolidation

Imagine you are analyzing two systems in a consolidation project. You make changes to roles and users in both systems. However, due to restrictions, you cannot yet apply changes in System A.

Without losing your work, you can:

  • Create a new consolidation using the dataset from System A and the modified snapshot from System B.
  • Or temporarily move the snapshot from System A into the dataset, and later reapply those changes when they are ready for production.

 Pic. 05 The Power of Management Snapshots and Datasets that are Used in Consolidation

This flexibility ensures you never have to redo your work and can manage changes efficiently.

Why Customers Prefer the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption

Customers appreciate the simulation feature because it provides:

  • System-level flexibility to manage changes.
  • Easy-to-handle snapshots that can be created, reviewed, reverted, and reused.
  • No duplication of effort, once a change is made, it is saved and can be reapplied.
  • Reliable validation, you can reload fresh production data and check if changes were successfully implemented.

If changes were tracked only at the consolidation level, fresh data from the system would overwrite them. This is why the Accelerator focuses on system snapshots, giving customers full control to experiment, validate, and roll back whenever needed.

 Pic.06 Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption Dashboard for Simulation Results Analysis

With the Accelerator for SAM4U Adoption, simulation becomes not just a test environment, but a strategic tool for efficient and risk-free SAM4U adoption.

entry.title: The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants
entry.content:
The Importance of Cross-Module Knowledge for SAP Consultants

In today‚Äôs dynamic SAP landscape, being a consultant means much more than mastering your own module. As a functional consultant in SAP MM, I‚Äôve learned over the years that success in real projects often depends on how well you understand the integration points with other modules.

   Why Cross-Module Knowledge Matters

End-to-End Processes: Business processes rarely stop at one module. A purchase order in MM eventually impacts FI through accounting entries, SD when linked to sales, and PP when it involves production. Without cross-module awareness, consultants risk missing critical dependencies.

Better Communication with Teams: Projects bring together FI, SD, PP, WM, and other consultants. Knowing their language and challenges helps avoid misunderstandings and ensures smoother collaboration.

Problem-Solving: Many issues reported by end users appear to be ‚ÄúMM problems,‚Äù but in reality, they stem from integration‚Äîsuch as GR/IR mismatches (MM‚ÄìFI), stock discrepancies (MM‚ÄìWM), or subcontracting issues (MM‚ÄìPP). A consultant with cross-module knowledge can resolve issues faster.

   Key Integration Areas for MM Consultants

MM‚ÄìFI: Inventory valuation, account determination, invoice verification.

MM‚ÄìSD: Third-party order processing, intercompany stock transfers.

MM‚ÄìPP: Material requirements planning, subcontracting, and production orders.

MM‚ÄìWM/EWM: Goods receipt, stock placement, and picking processes.

    Benefits for Your Career

Stronger Profile: Recruiters and clients look for consultants who can think beyond one module.

Added Value: You become a bridge between teams, often reducing delays in projects.

Future-Readiness: In SAP S/4HANA, processes are even more integrated, making cross-module knowledge a must-have skill.

    How to Build Cross-Module Skills

Learn from your colleagues on projects‚Äîask questions, join design workshops.

Explore integration scenarios in a training or sandbox system.

Follow SAP documentation and blogs focused on cross-functional processes.

Share knowledge within your teams and communities to reinforce your learning.

 

Final Thought: Mastering your own module is essential, but expanding into cross-module knowledge transforms you from a ‚Äúconsultant‚Äù into a true process expert. In the end, it‚Äôs not just about configuring SAP,it‚Äôs about understanding and optimizing business processes end to end.

entry.title: From Customer Org. Chart to SAP Org. Structure
entry.content:
Hello SAP Gurus,
While diving deep into the world of SAP ERP for over 10 years, I wanted to share some of my findings and experience on a topic that can be a challenge for many of us: How to Design the Customer‚Äôs Organization Hierarchy into SAP Enterprise Structure.

It's great to deploy what the SAP best practice says, but from the customer perspective it‚Äôs very sensitive step as it‚Äôs reflecting the overall business decisions. I recognized this during my career in implementing SAP projects, and I hope my findings can help you out there for whom might be starting on a similar journey.

Bridging the Gap Between Customer's Org. Chart and SAP Enterprise Structure

We all have our company's organizational chart hanging somewhere in the office or in a PowerPoint file. It shows the customer's department hierarchy, who reports to whom, and how teams are structured.

But how do we take that familiar hierarchy and map it to SAP's world of Company Codes, Plants, and Purchasing Organizations? It's not always a one-to-one match, and that's where the complexity (and honestly, the fun!) begins.

I found an example of this in old SAP Community question from 2008. A community user laid out a detailed case study of a company with 4 factories, 3 regional distribution centers, 15 sales offices, in addition of an R&D team and project management team. It was a fantastic real world scenario that highlighted the tough question we often face.

"since material from Plant and RDC is being transferred to Branches and from there it is distributed to customers therefore the valuation of FG at BRANCH and RDC should be different as transportation cost, packing, unpacking etc cost should get added at Branch level. Therefore in case I make branch as Storage location, I will miss the valuation part while if I make them as Plant then there will be lot of documents get generated for each movement."

This is exactly the kind of practical dilemma that gets to the heart of enterprise structure design. It's a constant balancing act between financial accuracy and operational efficiency.

Understanding The SAP Organizational Units

Before we define and assign the SAP enterprise structure, we need to know exactly what of each SAP org. unit represents. It‚Äôs helpful to think of them in a hierarchical way, starting from the top.

  1. Client: the highest level in the SAP system hierarchy. Specifications that you make, or data that you enter at this level are valid for all company codes and for all other organizational structures. You therefore only need to make these specifications, or enter this data once. This ensures that the data is consistent.
  2. Company Codes: is the central organizational unit of external accounting within the SAP System. You must define at least one company code before implementing the Financial Accounting component. The business transactions relevant for Financial Accounting are entered, saved, and evaluated at company code level.
  3. Plant: organizational unit serving to subdivide an enterprise according to production, procurement, maintenance, and materials planning aspects. It is a place where either materials are produced or goods and services provided.
  4. Purchasing Organizations and Purchasing Groups: An organizational unit subdividing an enterprise according to the requirements of Purchasing. It procures materials and services, negotiates conditions of purchase with vendors, and is responsible for such transactions. A purchasing group is a key for a buyer or group of buyers in SAP ERP. It is responsible for the procurement of a material or class of materials, and is the principal channel for a company's dealings with its suppliers.

Organizational Unit

Key Characteristics

Typical Use Cases

Client

Highest level, represents entire corporate group

One per SAP system

Company Code

Legal entity with independent financial statements

Subsidiaries, country operations

Plant

Operational unit where business activities occur

Factories, warehouses, sales offices

Storage Location

Physical storage area within a Plant

Warehouse sections, storage areas

Purchasing Org

Defines procurement scope and authority

Centralized or decentralized procurement

Purchasing Group

Actual procurement team or buyer

Commodity teams, regional buyers

A Visual Approach to Mapping

I'm a visual learner, so diagrams really help me solidify these concepts. I've created a couple of diagrams to illustrate how a typical departmental structure might map to SAP organizational units, and how those units relate to each other.
Here's a conceptual mapping from real-world departments to SAP units:

And here's a more detailed example of what a complete SAP organizational hierarchy might looks like, incorporating multiple company codes, plants, and purchasing organizations:

My Key Takeaways and Learned Lessons

After implementing a lot of SAP projects, here are some advices I have heard from my leaders:

Start with the "Why," Not the "What." Don't just create organizational units because they exist in your company. Think about your business processes and reporting requirements first. What do the customer need to see in his financial reports? How he manage his inventory? How do he want to analyze his procurement activities and expenses? The answers to these questions should guide you WHAT is the correct design decisions.

  1. The Plant is probably the most versatile org. unit in SAP. I've seen Plants used to represent everything from manufacturing facilities to service centers. Don't be afraid to think creatively about how to use Plants to model your business operations. Just remember that each Plant needs to be assigned to a Company Code, so plan accordingly. And remember that SAP defines the plant as a logistics organizational element that is used by all the logistics modules. The plant is assigned to a company code that may have many plants assigned to it. A plant is typically configured in conjunction with the company code and valuation area due to tax rules and regulations.
    Depending on the role the plant has in the organization, a plant can be defined for the following purposes:
    • In Sales and Distribution (SD), a location from which finished goods and materials are stored and distributed.
    • A location from which services are rendered.
    • Materials Management (MM), a location where material flow is managed and stock requirements are managed from both the inbound and outbound perspectives.
    • A location where material stock is consumed, planned, and purchased.
    • A manufacturing facility where materials are produced, as in Production Planning (PP).
  2. Purchasing org. structure has a huge impact on your procurement processes, approval workflows, and reporting. I learned that the hard way when we had to redesign our purchasing structure because we hadn't thought through the implications properly. Take time to understand whether a centralized or decentralized org. unit makes the most sense for your company.
  3. Plan for Growth and Change, Your first design probably won't be perfect, and your business will expand over time. Build flexibility into your design where possible, and don't be afraid to iterate, I've seen too many implementations get stuck because they tried to create the "perfect" structure from day one instead of starting with something good and improving it over time.
  4. Document Your Decisions, This might seem obvious, but document not just what you designed, but why you designed it. think in future questions, when someone ask why the regional sales offices are defined as plants instead of storage locations, you'll be glad that you wrote your reasoning.

Important Considerations

in past implementations i've encountered some comments from the customer that might help you think through your own design:

  1. Multi-Country Operations: If the customer operates in multiple countries, you'll likely need separate company codes for each country due to legal and tax requirements, but you might be able to share plants across company codes for operational efficiency.
  2. Shared Transactions: If the customer has shared service centers (like a centralized IT department or shared warehouse), think carefully about how to define and assign these on SAP, sometimes they're best represented as separate org. units, sometimes as cost centers within existing org. units.
  3. Acquisitions and Divestitures: If the company invest in other legal entities by frequently acquires or divests business units, design the SAP structure to make these transitions easier, this might mean keeping acquired companies as separate company codes initially, even if the customer plan to integrate them later.

Summery

SAP Enterprise Structure design is a piece of art, a part of business administration science, and a part of overall company growth.
There's no one "correct" way to do it, but there are definitely wrong ways, the key here is to understand customer business requirements, think through the implications of your design, and be prepared to adapt as you may learn later.

I hope my thoughts and findings has been helpful for you, and I'm always learning new things about SAP organizational structures, so I'd love to hear your thoughts and experiences.

  • What challenges have you faced when mapping customer's organization in SAP?
  • What advice would you give to SAP community members or for a someone has just starting out?
  • Have you encountered any particularly creative or unusual organizational structure designs?

entry.title: A Case Study: Mastering a Complex Rollout at a Utilities Enterprise
entry.content:
A utility company embarked on a transformative project focusing on process harmonization, establishing an ERP core as its backbone, and leveraging a merger with another enterprise to standardize processes while transitioning to S/4HANA. The rollout spanned a six-year roadmap involving more than 400 companies, 10+ countries, and over 30,000 SAP users.

The project‚Äôs complexity demanded significant attention and dedication. By its conclusion, the global team included around 10 workstreams, 25+ teams, and over 250 employees. What were the key success factors that enabled such an extensive and successful engagement?

Effective Planning

Thorough planning and preparation are fundamental to ensuring seamless cooperation and a successful go-live. In this case, the utilities company‚Äôs rollout adopted a targeted approach with clear goals. The initial rollouts for two pilot companies served as test runs to refine subsequent rollouts based on initial lessons learned.

In order to establish a Fit-to-Standard approach, a binding S/4HANA template was established, which was as closely aligned with SAP standards as possible, given the financial framework based on the analysis of the legal gaps. The template was built with the experts from all units to cover all requirements, which were later rolled out as the standard. Any exceptional requirements to enhance the template required a clear economic rationale, and local units had to justify the added value in case there were additional requirements. Remaining close to the SAP standard minimized the need for time-consuming custom developments, ensuring a rapid and efficient rollout. This approach minimized risks, controlled scope expansion, and reduced operational costs. The pilots tested the core template and helped derive valuable experience for a broader implementation.

Furthermore, the utilities company opted for a factory approach during the rollout of the project. Each factory had its tasks and responsibilities. The Test Factory, for example, ensured that E2E processes were tested and compliant with auditing standards and automation tools. The Migration Factory focused on data migrations with a specific standardized approach and tools to scale the migrations. The Cutover Factory ensured a successful and efficient go-live by leveraging cutover and steering tools, such as cutover plans and blueprints. The Communication and Change Factory‚Äôs task was to ensure the readiness of the people by informing, activating, and enabling all users with the respective knowledge transfer.

The utilities company‚Äôs ‚Äúfactory approach‚Äù balanced centralized governance with local execution. Central teams managed core activities like design, testing, and migration through specialized units, ensuring consistency and quality. Meanwhile, local teams addressed region-specific needs. This model fostered collaboration between central and local efforts, streamlining delivery and aligning global standards with local requirements. It enabled scalable, efficient rollouts by establishing a lean, standardized process and tool usage and ensuring transparency of all rollout steps.

Program Methodology and Governance

The customer opted for the SAP Activate methodology utilizing SAP Solution Manager (hereafter called SolMan) / Focus Build to ensure maximum transparency and run the project in an agile mode, enabling engagement of internal resources and time-efficient delivery despite COVID-19 remote work restrictions.

In the design and realization phase, the program scope was broken into three main waves, which were delivered by scrum teams, resulting in various agile sprint teams. SAP SolMan was the single source of truth, providing transparency and using scrum boards to ensure that all topics were tracked. The project also had clear guidelines and quality criteria, such as criteria for test completion and resulting documentation. The overall agile methodology, as well as SAP SolMan, resulted in the timely delivery of qualitative results by being responsive to changing requirements.

Strong program governance was another crucial factor. Initiatives of varying sizes and scopes benefit from centralized management and logical team clusters. Efficient project management methodologies and program leadership can significantly impact outcomes.

The utilities company‚Äôs governance structure included a lean finance stream supported by parallel integration and technology streams. Agile scrum teams managed deliverables dynamically, with 20 such teams driving the project forward. Over 90% of the scope was implemented within SAP standards due to robust and strict governance.

Strong governance also facilitated risk mitigation. Centrally organized meetings provided visibility to address key challenges promptly, such as restaffing roles when necessary. The utilities company and SAP collaboratively tackled issues, ensuring success through cross-team performance and motivated staff.

Structured Rollout Phases: The Core Fit2Standard Timeline

A critical enabler of the successful rollout was the structured sequencing of rollout phases within the Core Fit2Standard framework.

The utilities company adopted a phased approach that guided each rollout unit through clear steps of preparation, analysis, validation, and approval, ensuring alignment across all entities.

The process began with Local Units‚Äô Preparation, where onboarding, the collection of local information, and team setup established the foundation. This was followed by System Demos, introducing system landscape concepts and demonstrating template processes to ensure familiarity and clarity. The Local System Analysis phase identified requirements and gaps, including necessary local adjustments. These findings then moved into Template Validation, where potential gaps were discussed, categorized, and prioritized transparently.

After validation, the Review and Approval stage involved product owners and management making final decisions on gaps and their solutions, creating an efficient and constructive core Fit2Standard process. Finally, the Upload and Planning phase ensured that requirements were transferred to the backlog, dependencies were assessed, and handovers to the template team were executed smoothly.

Key success factors for this structured rollout included proactive participation in info sessions, thorough self-studies, and the use of InfoCollectors for pre-filled data gathering. Alignment between central and local units was emphasized, with local teams responsible for ensuring that regional requirements (e.g., legal obligations) were adequately addressed. Open discussion of potential gaps, along with clear prioritization, built trust and enabled efficient resolution. This structured phasing fostered transparency, minimized surprises, and kept the program aligned with the overall project roadmap.

Collaboration and Empowerment

Collaboration across teams and the entire project ecosystem is vital for smooth implementation. Effective change management‚Äîencompassing stakeholder management, awareness building, and resistance mitigation‚Äîcreates confidence and unity among affected teams.

The utilities company prioritized collaboration by adopting the philosophy ‚Äúfrom us for us,‚Äù engaging business, IT, central, regional teams, and partners. High levels of internal resource commitment ensured everyone actively contributed to the rollout. This large-scale engagement resulted in seamless cooperation among all parties involved.

One key lesson learned was the importance of separating program steering from content steering. Trusting system and topic owners to act in the company‚Äôs best interest proved invaluable. Addressing challenges directly as they arose ensured smooth progress. Additionally, a clear escalation procedure minimized hurdles and effort, contributing to the project‚Äôs success.

Furthermore, a key element of the project was the decision and escalation path, which vested more than 80% of the decisions by the product owners. These individuals took ownership and made decisions once unresolved topics were escalated to them. Product Managers were granted the mandate to make decisions related to cross-team matters. In this way, the product owners were empowered to take decisions and remained engaged, sharing a vested interest in the project‚Äôs success.

Driving Success in Rollout Management

The utilities company‚Äôs rollout exemplifies the principles of successful SAP implementations, especially for complex solutions like S/4HANA. Key factors included:

Effective Planning: Careful preparation, piloting, and the establishment of a binding Fit-to-Standard template ensured clarity of scope and minimized unnecessary custom developments.

Program Methodology and Governance: A robust governance framework, supported by the SAP Activate methodology and SAP Solution Manager, delivered alignment, transparency, and adaptability through agile execution and strong risk management.

Structured Rollout Phases: A transparent, phased Core Fit2Standard timeline guided each rollout unit from preparation through to planning, ensuring alignment across all entities and fostering consistent execution.

Collaboration and Empowerment: Unified teams with clearly defined responsibilities, empowered product owners, and a collaborative ‚Äúfrom us for us‚Äù philosophy fostered stakeholder engagement, accelerated decision-making, and ensured project ownership.

This case study demonstrates how disciplined planning, structured rollout phases, strong governance, and a collaborative culture can transform daunting challenges into scalable successes. For organizations embarking on similar transformative journeys, these strategies are not just recommended‚Äîthey are essential.

The lessons learned extend beyond technology. They highlight the importance of structure, discipline, and unity in navigating complex rollouts. By adopting these principles, organizations can achieve their goals while maintaining operational excellence and driving meaningful change.

entry.title: Standard ALV Line Selection instead of Checkbox in SAP
entry.content:
In many SAP reports, we build ALV outputs and allow the user to select certain rows for further processing.
A common approach is to add a custom checkbox column in the field catalog and capture user-selected rows.

But did you know?
üëâALV itself provides a built-in line selection mechanism ‚Äî no need for extra checkbox fields.
This makes your report look cleaner and behave more like standard SAP transactions (e.g., ME2N, ME23N).

In this post, I‚Äôll share how to enable row selection both in OOPs ALV (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID) and Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY), along with the benefits.


OOPs ALV with Container (CL_GUI_ALV_GRID):


Enable Line Selection

DATA: ls_layout TYPE lvc_s_layo.

ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.   " A = Multiple

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->set_table_for_first_display
  EXPORTING
    is_layout       = ls_layout
  CHANGING
    it_outtab       = gt_final
    it_fieldcatalog = gt_fcat.

 Fetch Selected Rows

DATA: lt_rows TYPE lvc_t_row,
      ls_row  TYPE lvc_s_row,
      lv_index TYPE sy-tabix.

CALL METHOD gr_alvgrid->get_selected_rows
  IMPORTING
    et_index_rows = lt_rows.   " selected row indices

LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
  lv_index = ls_row-index.         " Index in GT_FINAL
  READ TABLE gt_final INDEX lv_index INTO DATA(ls_final).
  IF sy-subrc = 0.
    " ---> Do your processing with ls_final
  ENDIF.
ENDLOOP.



Classical ALV (REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY)

Define Layout & Call ALV

DATA: ls_layout TYPE slis_layout_alv.
ls_layout-sel_mode = 'A'.  " A = Multiple

CALL FUNCTION 'REUSE_ALV_GRID_DISPLAY'
  EXPORTING
    i_callback_program      = sy-repid
    i_callback_user_command = 'USER_COMMAND'
    is_layout               = ls_layout
    it_fieldcat             = gt_fcat
  TABLES
    t_outtab                = gt_final.

 Handle User Command

FORM user_command USING r_ucomm     LIKE sy-ucomm
                        rs_selfield TYPE slis_selfield.

  DATA: lt_rows TYPE slis_t_row,
        ls_row  TYPE slis_row,
        ls_final TYPE your_table_type,
        lr_grid TYPE REF TO cl_gui_alv_grid.

  CASE r_ucomm.

    WHEN 'SUBMIT'.  " Custom button
      CALL FUNCTION 'GET_GLOBALS_FROM_SLVC_FULLSCR'
        IMPORTING e_grid = lr_grid.

      CALL METHOD lr_grid->get_selected_rows
        IMPORTING et_index_rows = lt_rows.

      LOOP AT lt_rows INTO ls_row.
        READ TABLE gt_final INDEX ls_row-index INTO ls_final.
        IF sy-subrc = 0.
          " -> process ls_final
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
  ENDCASE.
ENDFORM.

 
Advantages over Checkbox Selection

  1. Cleaner UI ‚Äì No need to add an extra checkbox column.

  2. Standard SAP Behavior ‚Äì Works like ME2N/ME23N where row selection is natural.

  3. Multiple Modes ‚Äì Single row, multiple row, column, or cell selection possible.

  4. Event Driven ‚Äì Double-click events can directly trigger detailed processing.

  5. Less Code ‚Äì No need to manage an extra field (X/space) for selection.

 

Conclusion

Whenever you design ALV reports, prefer standard line selection instead of custom checkbox fields.
It not only reduces development effort but also gives your users a familiar SAP standard look and feel.

Let me know if anyone tries this or if there's a better way to optimise it. I hope this helps! Let me know your thoughts or if you have any questions.

Thanks,

Akshay Anil   Linkedin Profile
Technical Consultant, SAP ABAP | BTP | Fiori | Ui5

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA 2025 Release New Functions
entry.content:
• LoB Affected:
  • New Functionality Added:
  • Asset Management
  • Consumer Products
  • Cross Applications
  • Defense & Security
  • Finance
  • Insurance
  • Manufacturing
  • Public Sector
  • R+D/Engineering
  • Retail
  • Sales
  • Service
  • Sourcing and Procurement
  • Supply Chain
  • Utilities

Hello Gurus üôÇ

Today i want to share with you my quick dive into the SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025, and see what is the most significant new functions added to the newer version exclusively.

Hope this blog be useful for you.

LoB Affected:

  1. Asset Management

  2. Consumer Products

  3. Cross Applications

  4. Defense & Security

  5. Finance

  6. Insurance

  7. Manufacturing

  8. Public Sector

  9. R+D/Engineering

  10. Retail

  11. Sales

  12. Service

  13. Sourcing and Procurement

  14. Supply Chain

  15. Utilities

New Functionality Added:

below table is illustrating what's new of 174 added functionalities per each LoB:

Asset Management

  • Maintenance Management

    1. Harmonized Documents in Maintenance Request Apps: With the Harmonized Document Management (HDM) functionality, you can now harmonize the process of handling attachments across different document management frameworks such as Document Management System (DMS), Generic Object Services (GOS), or Archive Link according to your business requirements.
    2. Recording Cooperation With Other Technicians: With this feature, you can determine that maintenance technicians should only be able to record time for another technician by scanning a QR code presented by that person.
    3. Verification of Maintenance Jobs: With this feature, a maintenance technician who has appropriate authorization, can verify jobs performed by another maintenance technician in the Perform Maintenance Jobs app (F5104A). This way, the maintenance technician who is doing the verification provides a quality check based on the principle of dual control.
    4. QR Code Scan Function for Filters in Find Maintenance Orders App: With this feature, you can fill filter fields in the Find Maintenance Orders (F2175) app by scanning QR codes that contain the corresponding filter values. When you scan a QR code with the scanner in the filter area, the system automatically enters the scanned values into the relevant filter fields and executes the search immediately with the relevant results.
    5. New Filter Parameters for Maintenance Order and Maintenance Notification: This feature enables master data specialists to set up geospatial data on objects based on the phase, subphase, notification and order processing contexts. This will help the maintenance planners, supervisors, and technicians to visualize and manage maintenance activities with greater specificity and accuracy.
    6. Original Final Due Date: With this feature, you can view the original final due date in addition to the previous final due date when the final due date is changed in a maintenance notification or a maintenance order. The original final due date indicates the final due date that was initially determined for a maintenance activity, whereas the previous final due date indicates the final due date before the most recent change. This means that the original value remains visible even when the value is changed several times.
    7. Maintenance Order: Dispatch of Individual Operations: With this feature, you can dispatch operations and suboperations of a maintenance order individually. Previously, this option was only available for additional operations in emergency orders and in the apps for Resource Scheduling.
    8. Billable Maintenance Order: Phase-Based Maintenance Process: With this feature, you can use phase-enabled order types to process billable maintenance orders. However, there are some differences in the approval process for billable orders compared to other order types.
    9. Self-Healing for Partner Inheritance: Partner Inheritance transfers partner functions and details from superior technical objects to child technical objects. Self-healing detects and corrects any inconsistencies, maintaining alignment and data integrity across the technical object hierarchy. This process eliminates manual intervention, reducing administrative overhead and the risk of inconsistencies.

Consumer Products

  • Direct Distribution

    • Last Mile Distribution for Direct Distribution
      • Management of Visit List Schedules: This feature introduces visit list schedules for strategic visit list planning.

Cross Applications

  • Integrated Business Communications

    1. Integrated Business Communications: Enable business users to communicate with customers, suppliers, and service partners through personalized, trackable, and scalable messages leveraging business context. Provide this communication initially through e-mail, with more channels to follow.
    2. Log Extension for Customer/ Supplier EoP Check: This feature enables you to get additional log information on why a certain customer/ supplier couldn't be blocked in the system.
    3. Spool Access Method Q: You can use the access method Q in the SAP spool system to print using print queues.
    4. Flexible Data Provider Integration: With this feature, you can use an external data provider of your choice to search for and populate validated data when creating new business partner records. This saves time when creating and researching new business partners. This function is only available if you have licensed and set up the appropriate external data provider. This feature leverages cloud integration capabilities within the SAP Integration Suite. Pre-generated SAP Cloud Integration content is available for the CDQ data provider from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. Note: This app is only available for cloud-ready mode.
    5. Data Context in the Extended Framework for Situation Handling: This feature enables you to also use data context in the extended framework for Situation Handling. Data context is business data from business objects involved in a situation instance that can be collected, distributed, and used for advanced analytics. If enabled in a situation type, data context is collected when a situation instance is created, updated, or completed.
    6. Custom SAP Object Types/SAP Object Node Types in Situation Objects: With this feature, you can use custom SAP object types and SAP object node types in situation objects.

Defense & Security

  1. Enhancements for the Critical Equipment: This product feature consists of various enhancements for the critical equipment: Migration for Critical Equipment Dismantling of Critical Equipment Technical Status Aggregation for Multiple Technical Status Profiles.
  2. Remote-to-Remote Server Communication Through the Central System: This feature provides the capability to use the central system to communicate from one remote server to another remote server in the same distributed landscape and then re-distribute the data. This supports the process of relocating technical objects and forwarding the notifications and work orders, assuring consistent data in the system landscape while operating at a remote site working offline in a communication-challenged environment.

Finance

  • Accounting and Financial Close

    • Closing Operations (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Ad Hoc Set and Item in Selections: With this feature, you can use Ad Hoc Sets and Ad Hoc Items as dimensions in selections and validation rules.
    • Corporate Close (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Additional Fields for Greenhouse Gas: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields for greenhouse gas in group reporting.
      2. Additional Fields for Public Sector: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields from the public sector industries in group reporting.
      3. Additional Fields for Financial Services: With this feature you can activate a business function that enables you to process additional fields from the financial services (FS) industries in group reporting.
      4. Display Master Data Change Log for FS Item: In the Define Financial Statement Items app, you can display a change log which shows all the changes that were done for a financial statement item (FS item).
      5. Release Universal Journal: Support of Prior Periods Mode: The release universal journal task now supports two prior periods modes for the accounting integration with group reporting preparation ledger: One for complete data in prior periods and one for delta data in prior periods.
      6. Cross-Version Balance Validation: With this feature, you can define validation rules that can compare figures between two consolidation versions, for example, Actuals vs Budget.
      7. Overwrite Rule Control Level for Balance Validation: With this feature, you can change the message type from Error to Warning for the balance validation tasks with task category Balance Validation in Accounting in the Define Balance Validation Tasks configuration activity.
      8. Activity-Based Consolidation of Investments: Change of Parent: When you change the parent unit in a consolidation group, the task for activity-based consolidation of investments now automatically posts the required entries. It adjusts the cumulative values of the balance sheet for all consolidation units of the consolidation group without an effect on earnings.
      9. Activity-Based Consolidation of Investments: Distribution of Dividends: When a distribution of dividends is reported, the consolidation process should proceed with the intercompany elimination of the dividends as well as the adjustment of the non-controlling interest (NCI). The intercompany elimination is done by the reclassification task. As of this release, you can report the dividend of an investee on dedicated FS items and the activity 18 (Distribution of Dividends). The C/I task supports the corresponding NCI adjustment based on corresponding reported data and the intercompany elimination result.
    • Financial Accounting (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. AVL Version 2 for Accounting View of Logistics Information
      2. Print/Email Payment Advice with SAP S/4HANA Output Management: This feature enables you to print or email payment advice with SAP S/4HANA Output Management.
    • General Ledger (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Calculation of Key Figures: With this feature, you can calculate the following additional key figures using the Calculate Key Figures (GADBKFC) report
      2. Depreciation Area for IFX and FAR: With this feature, you can specify depreciation area as an additional selection criteria while executing the following MCA processes: Currency Reclassification (IFX) Restatement (FAR)
    • Revenue and Cost Accounting (SAP S/4HANA)
      1. Fulfillment by External Percentage of Completion: You can fulfill relevant performance obligations (POBs) by the percentage of completion (PoC). In the past, this kind of fulfillment was enabled as manual fulfillment only. Now, a new event type is available for the fulfillment of PoC-based POBs: Event Type = PX (Fulfillment by External PoC). To fulfill POBs with this event type, the sender component must calculate the PoC progress and send a fulfillment revenue accounting item (RAI) with fulfillment information to Revenue Accounting and Reporting (RAR).
      2. Enhancement of the "Reprocess Account Determination" Report: The report Reprocess Account Determination (FARR_REPROCESS_ACCOUNTS) has been enhanced to support more selection fields. Up to now, the selection was made solely by using the revenue accounting contract as a mandatory field. With this enhancement, you can select the following main fields: Revenue Contract Company Code Accounting Principle You need to enter a value in at least one of these fields. Additionally, you can restrict your selection by using the fields Created By, Created On, Last Changed By, and Last Changed On, as well as by excluding completed contracts.
      3. Reference Group ID for Performance Obligations with Start Date Type 4: When fulfillments for performance obligations (POBs) with start date type 4 are canceled (for example, through a partial or full return), a cancellation fulfillment is created. For these cancellation fulfillments, the reference group ID is now stored in the fulfillment database table FARR_D_FULFILLMT. This enhancement allows you to easily identify which fulfillment has been canceled.
      4. Fulfillment by Customer-Specific Event Type: You can fulfill performance obligations (POBs) with a customer-defined fulfillment event type if the event types provided by SAP standard are not sufficient for your business scenarios and you would like to enhance them. Depending on the sender component, you need to trigger the creation of a fulfillment revenue accounting item (RAI) by a certain event and provide the corresponding fulfillment event type in the fulfillment RAI.
      5. Support of Cost-Based POC for Execution Order Items with Itemized Billing: This feature enables you to use cost-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for execution order items with the Itemized Billing billing relevance. The net value of the execution order item determines the planned revenue used in cost-based revenue calculation. The planned cost is the sum of all planned costs from the maintenance orders that are assigned to the execution order item.
      6. Support of the ‚ÄúRevenue-Based Percentage of Completion‚Äù Method for Fixed Price Execution Order Items: This feature enables you to use revenue-based percentage of completion (POC) revenue recognition for a) fixed price execution order items (with billing relevance Billing on Completion or Billing via Billing Plan After Release) and for b) not-billing relevant execution order items with price items as subitems. The planned revenue used in revenue-based revenue calculation comes from a) the net value of the execution order item or b) the sum of net values of all price items. The planned cost is the sum of all planned costs from the maintenance orders that are assigned to the execution order item.
    • General
      1. SAP S/4HANA Management Accounting Interface for Central Finance: With this feature you can enable online replication for certain postings from Management Accounting, provided both the source system and the Central Finance system run on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0.
      2. Central Market Segment Reporting: With this feature, you can enable reporting for service documents in your Central Finance system. To do so, the attributed profitability segment from the source system, which includes the service document information, is converted into a real cost object in the posting in the Central Finance System.

  • Billing and Revenue Innovation Management

    • Contract Accounting
      1. Submit to Collection Agency: Automatic Recall by API Collection Agency ‚Äì Confirmation: You can now process the recall of collection items automatically as part of data receipt by API Collection Agency - Confirmation.
      2. Import of Intraday Bank Statements: Using the Transfer Run for Bank Statements (FPB7P), you can now transfer intraday bank statement data. To do so, schedule transfer runs at the desired time intervals. The system only transfers new bank statement information to payment and return lots automatically.

If you manually change the plant and then want to change it back to the original value, you can use the Redetermine Plant/Location button in the Items assignment block.

Sourcing and Procurement

  • Central Procurement

    • Central Purchase Contract Processing
      1. Custom Split Criteria for Central Purchase Contracts: This feature allows you to customize how the Central Purchase Contracts are split and distributed to connected systems based on plant, storage location, and custom fields.
    • Central Purchasing
      1. Addition of New Fields in Purchase Order Extraction: This feature enables you to extract the Shipping Instruction and Price Printout fields from Purchase Orders (PO), both taken from the item-level fields in the PO data.

  • Operational Procurement

    • Purchase Order Processing
      1. Aggregation of Lean Service - Related Purchase Order History Items: This feature enables you to include lean service standard items as well as enhanced limit items in transaction ME87(Summarization and Removal of PO History Records).

  • General

    1. Allow Posting of Non-Valuated Good Receipts to Service Entry Sheets: This feature enables you to allow posting of non-valuated good receipts to Service Entry Sheets (SES).
    2. Service Master Data Migration Report to SAP S/4HANA: This feature enables you to transition from using MM-SRV in SAP S/4HANAto the Lean Service Product model. By running the RMMSRV_SRVMSTR_MIG_TO_S4 report, it converts your existing Service Master Data into the Lean Service Product format. This ensures your data aligns with the structural requirements of the SAP S/4HANA system, making the migration process smooth for our existing customers.
    3. Migration of Service Purchase Orders to Lean Services in SAP S/4HANA: This feature enables you to close existing service-based purchase order (PO) data from legacy tables and create new ones in the Lean format. Lean Services is SAP‚Äôs strategic solution for Service Procurement moving forward. While MM-SRV remains available, it will no longer receive functional enhancements.
    4. Migration of Service-Based Purchasing Contracts to Lean Contracts: This feature enables you to migrate service-based purchasing contracts from MM-SRV to Lean Contracts in the SAP S/4HANA system, based on user-defined input. It allows users to choose whether the migrated contracts should be created as hierarchical structures or as flat item lists.
    5. Mapping MM-SRV Document Types to Lean Services: This feature enables you to define a mapping between classic MM-SRV document types and their corresponding Lean Service document types in SAP S/4HANA .
    6. WBS Element Available in Service Entry Sheet Upload Template: This feature enables you to input the WBS Element directly in the Service Entry Sheet (SES) upload template instead of the internal WBS Element ID number.
    7. New Fields for Service Entry Sheet (Lean Services) API: This feature enables you to use the two new service-related fields Budget Period and Grant ID in the Service Entry Sheet (Lean Services) API.
    8. Non-Valuated Goods Receipt Supported in Purchase Requisitions: This feature enables you to define in the purchase requisition (PR) whether the goods receipt (GR) for a service should be non-valuated. The setting is transferred to the purchase order (PO) and determines how the GR is handled when posting the Service Entry Sheet (SES).

Supply Chain

  • Advanced Order Promising

    • Advanced Available to Promise
      1. ATP Categories in Availability Change Log: With this feature, the Availability Change Log (ACL) framework now records the ATP category along with the material, plant, MRP area, date, and time details for selected documents.
      2. Pool Segment as Planning Level in Supply Protection: This feature enables you to use pool segments as an additional planning level in supply protection. This allows the setup of supply protection, for example, for a specific quality grade. In such a case, supply protection could be set up in such a way that the articles with the highest quality are reserved for special protection groups such as key customers, whereas there isn't any restriction in place for lower-quality articles.
      3. Maximum Sequence Number in Alternative Determination: With this feature, you can use a new rating attribute to determine alternative confirmations for a requirement.
      4. With Creation of Stock Transport Document: With this feature, you can simplify logistical processes by triggering the automatic creation of transport orders to move stock from substitute plants or storage locations to the plant or storage location originally requested in an order.
      5. Rounding Confirmations in Sales Documents: With this feature, you can use rounding for confirmed quantities in sales orders and stock transport orders.
      6. Ability to Override Existing Confirmation Constraints: With this feature, users can override any existing Product Availability Check (PAC), Product Allocation (PAL) or Supply Protection (SUP) constraints to allocate confirmation to a requirement.
      7. Optimistic Reservation of Quantity: With this feature, you can configure the type of quantity reservation that is to be applied when the availability for a requested product is checked.
      8. Calculation of Supply and Demand for Subcontracting: With this feature, you can now configure how supply and demand is considered for product availability checks involving subcontracting scenarios.
      9. Batch as Planning Level in Supply Protection: This feature enables you to use batches as an additional planning level in supply protection. This allows for the protection of a specific batch of a vaccine. Batch identification can also be relevant for paints, chemicals, cosmetics, food, etc. In such a case, supply protection can be set up in a way that the quantities of a specific batch are reserved for special protection groups, while there isn't any restriction in place for other batches.
      10. Overprotection Alert in Supply Protection: Use this new standard template (CA_ATP_SUP_OVERPROTECTION) if you want your order fulfillment managers to be informed when the restrictions defined in Supply Protection lead to a critical availability situation when protected quantities are too high. Recipients can get notifications whenever the availability situation in combination with Supply Protection leads to a complete lock, or if single supply protection objects or single protection groups of related supply protection objects are locked.
      11. First Come First Served (FCFS) in Backorder Processing (BOP): With this feature, the system ensures that the availability check gives priority to earlier sales documents and stock transport orders even when later orders are altered.

  • Delivery and Transportation

    • Transportation Management
      1. Ocean Freight Tendering: With this feature, you, as a shipper, can use the direct tendering (non-RFQ) process to send a tendering plan or ocean freight booking directly to the carriers.
      2. Key Performance Indicators in the Transportation Cockpit: With this feature, you can display and evaluate key performance indicators (KPIs) in the transportation cockpit.
      3. Calculation of Distances Traveled with or Without Load: This feature enables you to have visibility regarding distances that are traveled either with or without load and whether the corresponding transportation stages are empty or not. Based on this information, you are able to measure the efficiency of your fleet by calculating the ratio of the distance traveled with load and the total distance, for example.
      4. New Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading: With this feature, you can use the handling execution status Cargo Ready for Loading, which, when so customized, starts the creation of customs invoice and export declaration before the goods are loaded onto a truck in an Advanced Shipping and Receiving process.

  • Inventory

    • Extended Service Parts Planning
      1. Assign Location Product-Specific Segmentations (Clusters): With this feature, you can assign location product-specific segmentations (clusters) to parts in the product master data within SAP S/4HANA and use them in the Extended Service Parts Planning processes. Clusters serve to group location products of the same kind. You define a cluster type for the criterion with which the clusters are to be formed.
      2. Consideration of Lead Time Variability in Multistage Safety Stock Calculation: This feature enables you to consider lead time variability measures when running the Multistage Safety Stock PSM service.
      3. Forecast Adjustment: This feature enables you to modify forecast results using a factor or a specific value. If you anticipate an increase or decrease in demand, you can adjust the forecast.
      4. OEM-Managed Inventory: With this feature, you can plan the stock of selected dealers. In this way, you can support these dealers in optimizing their procurement planning and stock situation. Furthermore, these dealers no longer need to order from you actively; as the original equipment manufacturer (OEM) and owner of Extended Service Parts Planning (eSPP), you trigger the transfer of stock to a dealer location for normal replenishment.
      5. Stock Monitoring Demand vs. Stock: This feature enables you to proactively manage inventory by providing timely notifications when stock levels fall below a critical threshold compared to the recent demand history quantity. This is particularly important for industries where maintaining the availability of specialized parts is a significant challenge.
      6. Stock Monitoring Phase-Out Forecast vs. Stock: This feature enables you to effectively manage the availability of End of Production (EOP) parts, supporting compliance with business and legal requirements for Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs). It addresses the challenges faced when suppliers discontinue the supply of EOP parts.

  • Warehousing

    • Warehouse Management
      1. Handling Execution Status: Cargo Ready for Loading: With this feature, you can set the handling execution status of a freight order to Cargo Ready for Loading or Cargo Not Ready for Loading in the Load or Unload Freight Orders app. You can use this feature if you want to conduct customs processes before a truck arrives at your warehouse.
      2. Reverse Goods Receipt after Final Put away for Stock from External Procurement: With this feature, you can also reverse goods receipt for stock from external procurement after final put away.
      3. Batch-Specific Units of Measure in Decentralized EWM: This feature enables you to work with batch-specific units of measure in decentralized Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) based on SAP S/4HANA during inbound, outbound, and internal warehouse processes, for example, physical inventory, warehouse-internal movements, or change posting.

Utilities

  1. New Time-Dependent Attributes for the Point of Delivery: In certain markets, for example in Germany, a point of delivery (referred to as the market location in Germany) can be changed to a ‚Äúdormant‚Äù status. Besides this new status, additional attributes must be also added as time-dependent to the point of delivery.
  2.
